title: 108_hr1874
content: The Act titled "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" clarifies the definition of homebound through a demonstration project. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" includes a demonstration project where Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions can receive home health services if certified as permanently homebound by a physician. The "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" establishes a demonstration project for Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions who are permanently homebound. The project allows individuals who require assistance with daily living activities, home health services, and technological assistance to receive care at home. The Secretary will collect data on the quality of care, patient outcomes, and any additional costs to the Medicare program. Reports to Congress are required within one year of the project's implementation. The demonstration project under the "David Jayne Homebound Reform Act of 2003" focuses on providing home health services to Medicare beneficiaries with chronic conditions who are permanently homebound. The Secretary will report to Congress on the project's quality of care, patient outcomes, and any additional costs to the Medicare program. Waiver authority is granted to conduct demonstration projects as necessary. The Secretary has the authority to waive compliance with certain requirements under the Social Security Act to conduct demonstration projects. This section does not waive any civil or criminal penalties under the Act. Authorization of appropriations is provided from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund. Authorization of appropriations is provided from the Federal Hospital Insurance Trust Fund and the Federal Supplementary Insurance Trust Fund under the Social Security Act for demonstration projects. Medicare beneficiaries are individuals entitled to benefits under part A or enrolled in part B of the Act. In this section, definitions are provided for terms such as "Medicare beneficiary," "home health services," "activities of daily living," and "Secretary." SEC. 3 clarifies the definition of homebound for determining eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program. The definition of homebound for eligibility for home health services under the Medicare program is clarified to include individuals with permanent and severe conditions requiring assistance with daily living activities and home health services. The Secretary may not disqualify such individuals from being considered 'confined to his home' based on absences from the home. The Secretary may not disqualify individuals with permanent and severe conditions requiring assistance from being considered 'confined to his home' based on absences. The Secretary must submit a report on the demonstration project's impact on home health services under Medicare by December 1, 2006. The Secretary must report on the impact of the demonstration project on home health services under Medicare by December 1, 2006. If the clarification of the definition of homebound adversely affects services or causes an unreasonable increase in Medicare expenditures, the project will be discontinued on January 1, 2007. The report must include specific data showing the increase in expenditures directly caused by the clarification. The report must include specific data on the increase in expenditures directly caused by the clarification and recommendations to exempt permanently and severely disabled homebound beneficiaries from restrictions on home health services under Medicare. Technical amendments are made to sections 1814(a) and 1835(a) of the Social Security Act. The report clarifies the criteria for home health services under Medicare, including absences from home.
